body: There were days upon days in New York City when not a single person was murdered in 2009. Two such stretches, in February and March, lasted nearly a week each. There were some pockets of the city where homicide was a singular occurrence: 12 of the city's 77 police precincts, in locations as varied as Hamilton Heights, in Upper Manhattan, and Park
title: HOMICIDES NEAR RECORD LOW RATE IN NEW YORK CITY

body: WHEN a real estate broker suggested that Jessica and Jonathan Marron rent an apartment in the Brittany, the same Upper East Side building where Mrs. Marron had lived as a teenager and where her parents and a sister still live, Mrs. Marron knew she would have to let her husband make the call. ''I was fine with it, because I'm very close to my
title: When Mom Is Just Floors Away

body: The anxiety and anger have been building all year. In March, a national coalition of Islamic organizations warned that it would cease cooperating with the F.B.I. unless the agency stopped infiltrating mosques and using ''agents provocateurs to trap unsuspecting Muslim youth.'' In September, a cleric in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, sued the government,
title: Muslims Say F.B.I. Tactics Sow Anger and Fear

''I have much love in this house,'' Ms. Gunderson, 56, said on a recent afternoon as she sat in the living room of her Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, apartment and gazed upon the faces of her 20-year-old
title: Makeshift Brood Frees Ailing Brooklyn Woman From Loneliness

body: The one constant in Calif Green's 36 years has been motion. A life that began in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, took him to North Carolina; Bay Ridge, Brooklyn; New Orleans; Atlanta; central Florida; prison; Macon, Ga.; Maryland; Key West, Fla.; a Harlem shelter; and ultimately, a three-bedroom apartment on the Rockaway peninsula so close to Kennedy
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; A Long and Winding Road Together

body: ''We can try/to understand/The New York Times effect on man,'' the Bee Gees once sang, to which we would say great. You might have at least as much fun just listening or singing or dancing to the rest of ''Stayin' Alive,'' which we bet has just wormed into your ear, where it will stay until at least bedtime tonight. Whether you're a brother or
title: EDITORIAL; Stayin' Alive

body: DAN SCHREIBER and Caroline Jeanjot took a one-bedroom sublet in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, after arriving in New York three years ago from their native Brussels. They chose it because of its low monthly rent, around $1,200, but knew little about the city's geography. Their Bay Ridge neighborhood was ideal in all ways but one -- the tedious subway ride to
title: THE HUNT; Going With Uncool

body: There are roughly six registered Democrats for every Republican in the city, but in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, Republicans are not hard to find. There is Nils Sinden, 78, an immigrant from Norway who has lived in the neighborhood for 60 years. There is Danny Loccisano, 32, who was born there and has never left. And there is Sofia Toliou, 25, who is from
title: N.Y.C. ELECTION 2009; BROOKLYN

body: Less than two years ago, the Brooklyn Brewery found itself in a bind that had squeezed many companies out of New York. It wanted to expand, but the rapid gentrification of its neighborhood, in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, had pushed rents beyond what it could afford. That was before the recession took hold in the city. Now, the brewery is taking
title: Soft Real Estate Market Is a Key Ingredient at Brooklyn Brewery

body: HALPIN--Eileen Marie (nee Callaghan), of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn passed away on October 4, 2009 at The Harborage. Beloved wife of the late William S. Survived by her loving brother, Thomas V. and sister-in-law, Dr. Sophie H. Pierog. Eileen was predeceased by her parents, Thomas V. (retired NYPD) and Margaret (nee Connors) as well as her sister Anne J.,
title: Paid Notice: Deaths HALPIN, EILEEN MARIE (NEE CALLAGHAN)

body: Halloween Events CLINTON HILL ANNUAL HALLOWEEN WALK Saturday, 5 to 6:30 p.m., a trick-or-treat walk for families through this Brooklyn neighborhood, with a map of locations provided by the Society for Clinton Hill, the walk's sponsor. It meets at the Pratt-Clinton Hill Community Garden, at the corner of Dekalb and Hall Streets;
title: Around Town

author: Lizzy Ratner is a journalist. Seth is the author, most recently, of the graphic novel ''George Sprott: (1894-1975).''
body: Even in this cheek-by-jowl town, the realm of other people's apartments remains resolutely mysterious. Sure, New Yorkers share walls, overhear fights, inhale the sweet-spiced victories (and, all too often, failures) of sundry kitchen experiments. But the odd, unholy secrets of our neighbors' homes remain hidden -- and some of these secrets are very
title: OP-ART; Nightmare on Your Street

body: In 2008, the Republican Party lost its sole New York City Congressional seat to Michael E. McMahon, a City Council member at the time. He became the first Democrat since 1981 to win the 13th District, which covers Staten Island and a portion of Brooklyn, the most conservative areas in the city. The Republican Party's difficulties in this stronghold
title: The City: Fight for Staten Island

body: WHEN they married last November, Mike and Sarah Hudnall had two plans for the near future: a new home and a new baby. They assumed there would be sufficient time to hunt for the former while waiting for the latter to happen. Instead, Mrs. Hudnall became pregnant immediately, so finding a place to buy became a priority. In their cozy Park Slope,
title: THE HUNT; New Home, New Addition

body: THE Smothers Brothers were born there. It's where Joe Louis took his Army physical. David Rockefeller once painted its restrooms. ''It'' is Governors Island, a 172-acre site, rich in history, that sits off the southern tip of Manhattan. ''Governors Island: The Jewel of New York Harbor'' (Syracuse University Press, $60), by Ann L. Buttenwieser, an
title: BOOKSHELF | FOR CITY EXPLORERS; A Military Past, an Unknown Future

body: Consider the facts of life for the two Republican candidates in the election next month for public advocate and city comptroller. Democratic voters in New York City outnumber Republicans by more than 5 to 1, giving the winners in the Democratic primary -- Bill de Blasio for public advocate and John C. Liu for comptroller -- such a big advantage
title: Republicans On the Trail, Going It Mostly Alone

body: Joe Newell, a police property clerk on Staten Island, would love for his brother, John, to get out of the Coney Island adult home where his television set and other property have mysteriously disappeared. But Mr. Newell remembers how the last time his brother lived on his own, he stopped taking his epilepsy medication and slipped on the ice,
title: For Families of Mentally Ill, Mixed Feelings Over Push Away From Adult Homes

body: Frail and dignified at 88, the man leaned on his cane and smiled as the story of his immigration in 1936 flashed behind him on a museum wall. Like tens of thousands of others who managed to come to the United States from China during a 60-year period when the law singled them out for exclusion, the man, Tun Funn Hom, had entered as a ''paper son,''
title: Immigration Stories, From Shadows to Spotlight

body: A Brooklyn money manager was arrested on Tuesday and charged with swindling hundreds of investors, including many retirees, out of $40 million in what prosecutors called a ''classic Ponzi scheme'' dating to the 1970s. Officials said the money manager, Philip Barry, put some of the money into real estate investments that did not pan out and some
title: Man Accused of Running Ponzi Scheme in Brooklyn

body: Since their inaugural season in 2001, the Brooklyn Cyclones have been a remarkable success story: locals have embraced the minor league club for returning baseball to the borough after a nearly half-century absence, as overflow crowds have poured into the Coney Island ballpark year after year. Winning has not hurt either: the Cyclones have missed
title: Despite Success, Fewer Fans Cheer Cyclones

body: IT would be wrong to begin with anything but the beach. This tiny neighborhood, a mere four by eight blocks of the Rockaway peninsula in southern Queens, is bounded to the north by Jamaica Bay and to the south by the Atlantic Ocean. That proximity to the ocean defines Neponsit, from its blocks of waterfront mansions to the chummy neighborhood
title: LIVING IN | NEPONSIT, QUEENS; A Beach Shared by a Tight-Knit Clan

body: The coming season will see many repeat performances, as chefs and restaurateurs move to new locations or replicate existing establishments. title: Branches

body: The automated public toilet at National Street and Corona Plaza in Queens -- a self-cleaning contraption that douses itself with disinfectant after each use -- is a prince among lavatories. A stone's throw from the elevated tracks of the No. 7 train, translucent panels jut from a roof topped with a pyramidal skylight. Gender-specific pictographs
title: A Sidewalk Oasis, if You Can Find One

body: One by one, they trundled and coughed their way into the nation's car dealerships: Astro minivans with aqua pinstripes, low-slung Buick Centuries, Chevy Tahoes in that slightly chlorinated dark green of the late 1990s, all headed for the junkyard of history. ''Clunker,'' the salesmen scribbled on their windshields in waxy crayon, or slapped on
title: Drivers Are Rushing to Dealerships as 'Cash for Clunkers' Program Winds Down

body: JUST as New Yorkers become part of the summer patchwork on the beaches of Long Island and the Jersey Shore, another group reverse-migrates to New York City for the warm months: college interns. For decades, interns have served as coffee gofers in the financial district and entered data behind the walls of corporate cubicles in Midtown. But this
title: Interns Find a Will, a Way, a Floor

body: Empire State Signals Q.Now that there is no broadcasting of TV channels over the airwaves, what purpose do the antennas on top of the Empire State Building serve? A. Television and radio signals, just as before. ''The only change has been that analog has been shut off and replaced by digital,'' the building's management said in a statement. ''There
title: F.Y.I.

body: It wasn't a good moment to be the only member of the City Council who turned down an official parking pass, which allows members to park virtually anywhere. Councilman Tony Avella was racing to Kopperfields restaurant in Bay Ridge, where one of the few groups supporting his insurgent mayoral campaign was gathering. He circled the block in his
title: Insurgent Candidate Fights Elitism, and Bloomberg

body: THREE in the morning had come and gone on Sunday when the band went onstage, but the dance floor at the El Morocco club in Hamilton Heights had been packed for hours. As soon as La Banda Gorda, which had flown up from Santo Domingo for the show, broke into the telltale galloping rhythm of merengue, the crowd erupted with applause and joyous shouts
title: New York Rhythm: Viva la Variedad!

body: THE Tesla Roadster was made for California. The all-electric convertible sports car accelerates about as fast as a Porsche 911 Turbo, but gets nearly three times the mileage equivalent of a Toyota Prius. It's as lean and athletic as a pro surfer and as guilt-free as a cup of chamomile tea. It's also more than $100,000, making it the perfect car for
title: Taking a Tesla for a Status Check in New York

body: CALL them members of the Obama generation: Seven of New York City's valedictorians, invited to discuss the future -- theirs, the city's, the world's -- could not help circling back to themes resonant from President Obama's historic campaign: diversity, globalization, cooperation, hope. ''We're that high school class that was there when Obama got
title: The Future Is Theirs

body: Until it implodes with preposterous plot manipulations, ''The Narrows,'' directed by François A. Velle, can be appreciated as the film equivalent of a reasonably palatable pasta dish concocted from a familiar recipe and served in a no-frills restaurant. Its eager-beaver protagonist, Mike Manadoro (Kevin Zegers), is an aspiring photographer from an
title: MOVIE REVIEW | 'THE NARROWS'; Weaned on the Thug's Life, but Pulled Toward Grander Ambitions

body: THE hookahs looked like exotic animals lurking in Hookahnuts, a shop for gifts and food in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. In various shades of red, blue and green, these water pipes, used to smoke flavored tobacco, were the most vivid sign of the shop's Middle Eastern culture, presented among an eye-catching array that included intricate wooden trays,
title: Festival for New York, That Muslim City

title: Inside the Times

body: A CALL TO COUNTERS And Bee Lovers Scientists and park officials want you, urban dweller, for the Great Pollinator Project, a bee-counting program started two years ago. The goal? Count how many bees live in the five boroughs. Aspiring bee counters can learn to participate in a series of orientations this month, and are then given seeds and plants
title: CITY ROOM BLOGGING AT NYTIMES.COM/CITYROOM.

body: SPOKES: LEARNING To Ride...at 18 As New York City goes through something of a bicycling renaissance -- with the construction of new bike routes and improved bike parking -- one issue has received little attention: There are some New Yorkers -- and I'm not talking about 5-year-olds -- who do not know how to ride. Until I was 18, I was one of them.
title: CITY ROOM BLOGGING AT NYTIMES.COM/CITYROOM.

body: They are younger than their predecessors, have less experience in the classroom and are, most often, responsible for far fewer students. But their salaries are higher and they have greater freedom over hiring and budgets, handling a host of responsibilities formerly shouldered by their supervisors. Among the most striking transformations of New
title: CONTROLLING INTERESTS; Principals Younger and Freer, But Raise Doubts in the Schools

body: The death of a teenager who collapsed after a fight at a party in Prospect Park in March has been ruled a homicide, but the authorities said Thursday that the four people arrested on gang assault charges in the case would not face any additional charges. The medical examiner ruled this month that the March 8 death was a homicide because the
title: Homicide Ruled in Collapse Of Youth After Fight in Park

body: THEY said nothing could replace Mooney's Pub. For almost a year, they were right. The old bar, which had stood on Flatbush Avenue near Seventh Avenue in Prospect Heights since before Brooklyn was fashionable, closed in a rent dispute last June, after a rollicking Saturday night when the air-conditioning broke and people crowded in anyway. The next
title: DISPATCHES; A Bar -- a Bar! -- Where the Pub Used to Be

body: YEAR-ROUND sunshine is hardly guaranteed, and mah-jongg tiles have not turned up in bulk just yet. But Charleston, on Staten Island's southwestern shore, is making a bid to take Florida's mantle as a destination for the region's elderly, with a trio of new and planned developments: the Tides at Charleston, Charleston Towers and Kreischerville. For
title: Catering to a Grayer Crowd

body: Myra Alperson is a matchmaker of sorts. She brings together people curious about exploring the city and introduces them to out-of-the-way neighborhoods they may never have visited. And like Napoleon's army, her crew travels on its stomach. An effervescent and ambulatory Zagat, Ms. Alperson has for 10 years run culinary tours that she calls
title: BAY RIDGE JOURNAL; Changing Tastes, From Lingonberry to Baba Ghanouj

body: A culinary tour in a Brooklyn neighborhood introduces people to a smorgasbord of tastes.
title: A NoshWalk Through Bay Ridge

body: TOFU TAKEDOWN In the spirit of two wholly American pursuits -- overeating and winning -- comes the Takedown, a cooking competition where anything goes. Held in bars around town, it pits a few dozen mostly amateur contestants against one another in battles centered on dishes like chili (above), salsa or cookies. There are judges, audience favorites
title: Spare Times

The first thing that strikes you about him, when you take a break from the clatter of the bowling lanes and pad into the
title: THE VOICE; A Little Eschatology With That Bud?

body: DEAR DIARY: It was shortly after the debut of the movie ''Fargo.'' My elegant Minnesota sister (from Lake Wobegon country) and I passed the venerable Steinway piano store on our way to Carnegie Hall. She admired a piano on display and waxed rhapsodic (and quite loudly) about its grand features. She is, after all, a piano teacher. A passing
title: Metropolitan Diary

body: The more than 100,000 counterfeit items seized this week from a warehouse in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, included the usual fare of fake designer clothes and handbags. But besides the counterfeit Ralph Lauren shirts, Coach purses and other items found in rented storage spaces inside the warehouse, there were 17 pairs of fake Nike sneakers that bore not
title: Counterfeiters Favored Nike, and Obama, Too

body: Lose your job in Boston, Pittsburgh, Seattle or Trenton and you could collect $544 or more per week in unemployment benefits. But get laid off in New York City, as almost 200,000 workers have in the past year, and the most you can collect is $430 a week. Despite its high cost of living, New York pays less to its unemployed than about two dozen
title: New York's Newly Jobless Find $430 a Week in Benefits Doesn't Go Far

body: AS a setting for romance, the rolling thunder of a subway car, careening through the depths of Manhattan, is not high on the lists of most New Yorkers. But that's where love found Sarah Feldman and Jeffrey Laite one morning in January 2007. Ms. Feldman, known as Dixie, was in the middle of a heartbreak-induced depression when she left her Midtown
title: VOWS; Dixie Feldman and Jeffrey Laite

body: A humpback whale was spotted for several hours Thursday in New York Harbor near the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, the Coast Guard said. The whale, which was first reported to the authorities by a resident's phone call around 8 a.m., did not appear to be injured or entangled. ''It's going out toward the ocean,'' said Petty Officer David Schulein, a
title: Humpback Whale Visits New York Harbor, Protected by Coast Guard

body: ''I'M co-opting you, I made blueberry muffins!'' Giulia Melucci hollers before you've even crossed the threshold to her Brooklyn apartment. The muffins are warm from the oven and finished with a dip of melted butter, then sugar. Who wouldn't be co-opted? The answer is the string of men Ms. Melucci, 42 and perpetually single, writes about in ''I
title: AT HOME WITH GIULIA MELUCCI; Romeo Is Late For Dinner

body: He is comfortably ahead in the polls. He has the vast powers of incumbency at his disposal. He has the backing of the city's most powerful business interests. But that does not seem to be enough for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. As his campaign sought to overpower any candidate considering challenging him, Mr. Bloomberg commissioned a telephone poll
title: Phone 'Survey' For Bloomberg Attacks a Rival

body: IN 1885, when Brooklyn was still an independent city, the St. George Hotel was rising on Clark Street, just steps from the East River. At 2,623 rooms, it would become the nation's largest and grandest hotel. By the early 1930s, its new tower rose more than 30 stories. Occupying an entire block of Brooklyn Heights, between Hicks, Henry, Clark and
title: BROOKLYN HEIGHTS; Trying to Recapture the Glory Days, Up in the Old Hotel

body: New York is a city of speed walkers, but the bus stop on the corner of Third Avenue and Bay Ridge Avenue in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, has the look of a video clip of the city playing in slow motion. On Wednesday afternoon, a petite woman in sunglasses made her way with a cane to a friend who was already at the stop. An elderly woman with a walker also
title: BIG CITY; With No B37, Bay Ridge Gets Too Big

body: NANCY AND AZIZ LAMAZOU hail from Lebanon and Tunisia. During Mr. Lamazou's years as a diplomat, they ate their way across the globe. They're purveyors of fine European packaged goods. They cave continental cheeses beneath a New York City sidewalk. They sell carefully made sandwiches. Nicky Defonte, born and raised in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, is the
title: $25 AND UNDER; Within Six Blocks, Worlds Apart

body: Hours before its official record release show on Tuesday night the Brooklyn indie pop band Bishop Allen played a private concert at McGarry Bowen, an ad agency in Chelsea: a not uncommon gig at a time when many musicians make their living off commercials and licensing deals. Later it performed to a nonpaying capacity crowd at Other Music, the
title: Becoming Professional, Just Not Self-Important

body: A Brooklyn teenager chasing a group of unruly young men and the father of one of them from a party in Prospect Park just after midnight on Sunday collapsed and died after suffering what appeared to be a heart attack, the victim's friends and the police said. The youth, Sharif Abdallah, 17, who lived in Carroll Gardens, was not visibly injured in
title: Brooklyn Youth, 17, Dies in Fracas at Party

author: Mark Levine teaches at the Iowa Writers' Workshop.
body: MY NEIGHBOR JOE EMBRACED THE ZEITGEIST, or was embraced by it, shortly before Thanksgiving a couple of years ago when he decided to bid adieu to his S.U.V., a two-and-a-half ton specimen that was a pain to park, got only slightly better mileage than a cement mixer and bore a brand name that meant to evoke, through misspelling, a famously resilient
title: Share My Ride

body: Around midnight Friday, the Rev. Gilbert Luis R. Centina III appeared outside his church in East Harlem, long past the office hours posted on the rectory door, asking people if they wanted to come in and confess their sins. At that hour, on that sidewalk, with the hood of his robe pulled tight over his head, Father Centina could be described as a
title: Extended Hours, One Day Only: Absolution in the City

body: It is lunch hour in Times Square on a numbingly cold Tuesday. The five-story-high advertisements wink at the world. title: ABOUT NEW YORK; Brave Producers Break Into Opera At a Grim Time

title: GENERATION B; The Ram vs. Tito Santana

body: BEING stuck in traffic on the Long Island Expressway isn't known as a spur to creativity (except of the colorful-expletive variety). But it worked out that way for Stan Schofield, a filmmaker who divides his time between Hampton Bays and Manhattan and used his enforced idleness on the L.I.E. to come up with the idea for a movie. While
title: Film Festival Celebrating 25 Years With 22 Features

body: Stretched thin in Afghanistan and Iraq, the American military will begin recruiting skilled immigrants who are living in this country with temporary visas, offering them the chance to become United States citizens in as little as six months. Immigrants who are permanent residents, with documents commonly known as green cards, have long been
title: U.S. Military Will Offer Path To Citizenship

body: A Staten Island doctor was charged on Tuesday with operating a walk-in clinic that illegally prescribed steroids to more than 200 customers, prosecutors said, including one bodybuilder with a transplanted heart who eventually died from taking the drugs. The doctor, Richard Lucente, 37, ran a health clinic called the New York Anti-Aging and Wellness
title: S.I. Doctor Faces Charges in Steroid Case

body: A Brooklyn neighborhood pharmacy, a doctor and his health clinic have been indicted on charges related to the illegal sale of steroids, the Brooklyn district attorney's office said Tuesday. The doctor, Richard Lucente, 37, of Staten Island, was charged with the criminal sale of a prescription for a controlled substance, reckless endangerment and
title: Charges for Steroid Sales in Brooklyn

body: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Bishop Nicholas A. DiMarzio of the Diocese of Brooklyn unveiled a proposal on Saturday to convert four Roman Catholic schools singled out for closing into public charter schools, an 11th-hour lifeline meant to preserve the education provided in the buildings and stave off potential overcrowding in city schools. It
title: Mayor and Bishop Announce Plan to Turn 4 Catholic Schools Into Charter Schools

body: One elevator mechanic said he liked to have a beer or two on the job. Another employee disappeared for hours at a time. title: City's Elevator Mechanics Caught Skipping Work, Documents Show

body: ''Here,'' said Eddie Byrnes. He waved his hand at a bare wall in a wholesale food warehouse in Brooklyn. ''This is where they usually keep the wings,'' said Mr. Byrnes, who buys food for the Kettle Black Bar and Restaurant in Bay Ridge. He squinted at a stack of boxes nearby that were full of chicken parts, all of them wrong. Drumsticks. Breasts.
title: ABOUT NEW YORK; A Super Bowl Victory, Answering a Prayer for Wings

body: She pronounces the words gently, as if they were incantations that could make objects materialize. Walking into her bedroom -- which is dark because of a burnt-out overhead light bulb she cannot quite persuade the landlord to replace -- Carmela Scarpulla lists the things she needs and cannot afford: ''A dresser. A little table. A lamp.'' It is not
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; Regaining Independence, But Losing Some Support

body: THOUGH Christine and David Crowe were eager to downsize, they were apprehensive. After three decades, they would be going from a two-level house on Long Island with four bedrooms and three bathrooms to a one-bedroom one-bath apartment in New York City. With their three children grown and retirement ahead, ''all the things we moved to Long Island
title: THE HUNT; The City Experiment

body: When she felt a lump, in December 2007, Jackqulyn McMillan feared it was her turn. One of her seven sisters, Anna Cook, had breast cancer and died in 1982. Another, Gwen Wood, had lung cancer and died in 1993. Gaynell McMillan, another sister, got a diagnosis of breast cancer in 1999 and, after a lumpectomy, survived. And one more sister, Viola
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; Lost Ground in a Standoff With Cancer

body: The Diocese of Brooklyn has proposed closing 14 elementary schools at the end of the current academic year, a plan that would mean that one of the nation's largest Catholic dioceses would have shuttered nearly 40 percent of its grade schools in the past seven years. The proposed closings and mergers, announced on Monday, are the latest retrenchment
title: Brooklyn Diocese Moves to Shut 14 Schools as Enrollment Slides

body: EVEN if the latest economic slump stunts the explosion of New York's population before the end of the decade, you can count on the fact that the city's proverbial changing neighborhoods will keep changing. Detailed census figures released last month and analyzed for The New York Times by Andrew Beveridge, chairman of the sociology department at
title: NEW YORK BY THE NUMBERS; Neighborhoods, Up Close and Personal

body: A New York City wastewater treatment plant worker was killed early Friday when a temporary conveyor belt collapsed, crushing him under its steel supports, city officials said. The accident occurred about 8:30 a.m. as workers at the site, the Owl's Head Wastewater Treatment Plant, in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn were moving the conveyor belt --
title: City Worker Crushed to Death at Sewage Plant in Brooklyn

body: Like many of the Italians who frequently visit the Amico senior center in Borough Park, Brooklyn, Salvatore Amato, 78, who arrived here from Sicily in 1958, speaks little English. Some, like Luigi Buonincondro, 91, a former Italian soldier who came to New York from Naples in 1961, understand English, but have a hard time reading or writing it. ''I
title: For Italians in Brooklyn, the Faces and the Voices on the Streets Have Changed

body: Anger over the Israeli assault on Gaza spilled into Times Square on Saturday, as hundreds of protesters condemned the attacks in a demonstration that stretched four blocks and clogged much of the city's central tourist district for several hours. The protest came as Israeli troops began a ground incursion into the Hamas-controlled territory in what
title: Rally Protests Fighting in Gaza

body: While other eyes were on the ball dropping in Times Square, a lucky few New York City police commanders were looking down at a similar shape before them, the little oval in the 2008 statistics under the column marked ''murder.'' If you listened closely this week, you could hear the rapping of knuckles on old desktops in the commanders' precinct
title: Precincts With the Best New Year: No Homicides in '08
